importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date the news article was published, indicating the most current update on the ongoing flooding crisis in Mexico.
This is a placeholder date for the event occurrence, but the actual flooding occurred last week, with the peak rainfall reported on Wednesday (exact date not specified).

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding and resulting deaths occurred during a recent period of heavy rainfall, emphasizing the suddenness and severity of the disaster.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to flooding in five states caused by heavy rains from Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported 65 people still missing, with the highest death tolls in Veracruz (29), Hidalgo (21), and Puebla (13).
The heaviest rainfall—280mm in Cerro Azul, Veracruz, and 286mm in Cuetzalan del Progreso, Puebla—occurred on Wednesday, triggering floods and landslides.
Thousands of military personnel from the Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to deliver food, water, and emergency aid to affected areas.
More than 80% of electricity supply has been restored across the five affected states, where about 263,000 users lost power.
Early estimates show that around 100,000 homes have been severely affected, with some near rivers nearly disappearing due to flooding.
Mexico’s meteorological services state there were no early warning signs indicating the extreme rainfall, raising questions about the country’s disaster alert system.

namedEntities.name: Mexico
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The primary location affected by the flooding and the context of the human and environmental impact.

namedEntities.name: Laura Velazquez Alzua
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chief of the National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She provided official updates on the death and missing tolls during the government briefing.

namedEntities.name: Claudia Sheinbaum
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She led the national response and addressed the public during a daily news briefing, indicating her role in overseeing disaster management.

namedEntities.name: Veracruz
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A state in Mexico's southeastern coastline
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the most affected states, with 29 deaths and 18 missing people.

namedEntities.name: Hidalgo
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Reported 21 deaths and 43 missing people, making it a major site of impact.

namedEntities.name: Puebla
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Record rainfall in Cuetzalan del Progreso caused significant flooding and 13 deaths.

namedEntities.name: Queretaro
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One death was confirmed in this state, indicating minor but measurable impact.

namedEntities.name: Cerro Azul
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Reported the heaviest rainfall (280mm), contributing to the severity of flooding.

namedEntities.name: Cuetzalan del Progreso
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Reported 286mm of rain, one of the highest rainfall totals, directly linked to flooding.

namedEntities.name: Hurricane Priscilla
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A tropical storm that weakened and contributed to the rainfall
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The remnants of Hurricane Priscilla were a key cause of the extreme rainfall and flooding.

namedEntities.name: Tropical Rainstorm Raymond
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A tropical storm contributing to the rainfall
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Together with Hurricane Priscilla, its remnants caused rivers to rise and triggered landslides and floods.

namedEntities.name: National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Mexican agency responsible for disaster response
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Led the official coordination of the disaster response and provided the official death and missing numbers.

namedEntities.name: Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Deployed to deliver food, clean water, and medical supplies to isolated areas affected by landslides and road closures.

namedEntities.name: Electricity officials
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Government officials responsible for power restoration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Reported that over 80% of power has been restored in five states, with about 263,000 users previously without power.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond caused catastrophic flooding across five Mexican states, resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 missing persons. The worst-hit areas were Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), and Puebla (13 deaths), with extreme rainfall recorded in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso. Thousands of military personnel have been deployed to deliver emergency aid, and nearly 80% of electricity has been restored. The incident has raised serious concerns about Mexico’s early warning systems, as meteorologists note no prior signs of such extreme rainfall.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
